(BN) (NS-Election-Protest)</p><p>Several protesters spent the night in tents across the street from Nova Scotia Premier Russell MacLellan's house.</p><p>They live near the Sydney tar ponds and all of them want the province to buy their homes.</p><p>Ann Ross, one resident, says she told the premier she doesn't want to go home.</p><p>MacLellan says he can't be sidetracked by the protest. (CJCB) (Irving-Whale-Spill)</p><p>A coast guard official says he doesn't think the bulk of P-C-B contamination leftover from the Irving Whale came from the lift of the barge.</p><p>A report by Environment Canada suggests a large volume of the toxic chemical spilled during the 1996 operation.</p><p>Jack Gallagher, of the coast guard, will not deny the report, but remains skeptical.</p><p>An environmentalist says Ottawa won't admit to the leak because it might hurt the lawsuit against Irving Oil to recover the lift cost. (BN) (NB-Forest-Fire)</p><p>New Brunswick forest fire crews had a busy weekend.</p><p>Crews were called out yesterday to battle a woodlands blaze near Bathurst that burned 20 hectares.</p><p>Willy Cull of the province's Forest Fire Centre in Fredericton, says unless there's some rain there will be more fires.</p><p>A weather forecaster for Environment Canada says rain is not expected. (Moncton Times and Transcript) (Churchill-Profits)</p><p>A new deal for the Upper Churchill Falls hydro project will mean an extra one-billion dollars for Newfoundland's treasury.</p><p>Premier Brian Tobin says the agreement extends over 40 years.</p><p>It was ratified Friday by the province and Hydro-Quebec. (VOCM) (PEI-Ferries)</p><p>Another sure sign that summer is here…</p><p>Northumberland Ferries has added to two extra crossings between Nova Scotia and P-E-I.</p><p>It's to accomodate the influx of tourists to the region.</p><p>The company is expected to kick into high-gear with more daily sailings after June 30th. (CFCY)</p><p>(Atlantic Update by Murray Brewster)</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:5STV-MB51-DY9S-T242-00000-00Smoke clogs Yosemite Valley as firefighters battle blaze2018-07-18T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:18:58ZLexisNexisINTERNATIONALSmoke clogs Yosemite Valley as firefighters battle blazeSmoke clogs Yosemite Valley as firefighters battle blazeThe Associated Press

MARIPOSA, Calif. - Hot and dry weather on Tuesday hindered efforts to slow the growth of a forest fire near Yosemite National Park that killed a California firefighter last weekend, leading some tourists to cut short their visits although all park trails remained open.

The blaze roaring through dry brush and timber between the town of Mariposa and Yosemite National Park has scorched more than 19 square miles (49 square kilometres) in steep terrain on the park's western edge, the U.S. Forest Service said.

More than 1,400 firefighters were battling the flames threatening more than 100 homes and businesses, the Forest Service said. It's just 5 per cent contained.

An inversion layer trapped smoke in the area, limiting air attacks and leading officials to issue a hazardous air alert, saying people with health conditions should stay indoors.

"Use common sense. If it looks smoky outside it's probably not a good time to go for a run. And it's probably not a good time for your children to play outdoors," Mariposa County officials said.

Alyssa Sandoval of Pollock Pines, California, planned to leave the park Tuesday. But she left a day early after spending a couple hours in a smoke-filled valley.

"The smoke was horrible, it was horrible. My mother got sick, my husband's eyes were stinging, burning," she said. "I've never seen the valley like that. It was smoked out. You didn't even know you were in Yosemite."

All amenities and trails remained opened Tuesday, and park rangers tending the entrances and the visitor centre were informing tourists of the poor air quality, park spokesman Scott Gediman said. Information was also posted on the park's social media accounts.

"Our primary goal is get the information out to them so they can decide how best to go about their visit," Gediman said.

Air quality monitors showed particulate levels in the park at "very unhealthy" levels, meaning everyone should avoid prolonged or heavy exertion or risk serious health effects such as respiratory problems.

Yet tourists plan their visit to Yosemite months or even years in advance. So far, there have been few cancellations, Gediman said.

Images posted to social media showed billowing smoke completely obscuring Half Dome, an iconic rock formation. Park webcams showed other landmarks, such the El Capitan rock formation, at times concealed by thick plumes of smoke.

Graduate student Paul Schlesinger, 28, said the smoke-choked air and raining ash forced him and a group of friends to change their plans to hike up to Glacier Point, which normally offers sweeping views.

But after driving for 90 minutes from Fresno and waiting in a 5-mile long line of cars to enter the park on Sunday, they decided to instead hike in Mariposa Grove.

"We didn't think it was worth exposing our lungs to that air when you couldn't see anything but also wanted to take advantage of our day there," he said.

A high pressure system was trapping the smoke that is polluting the air, and the same weather phenomenon is expected Wednesday, National Weather Service forecaster Cindy Bean said.

There is a possibility of thunderstorms Thursday, which could bring erratic winds and create containment problems for fire crews, Bean said.

A big concern is thousands of dead trees that were killed by an epic drought that has gripped California for several years.

On Monday, crews retrieved the body of heavy fire equipment operator Braden Varney, 36, after he died in steep terrain on Saturday. Firefighters took turns keeping vigil near Varney's body and saluted as it was taken to a coroner's office.

The blaze that started Friday prompted officials over the weekend to order the evacuation of the Yosemite Cedar Lodge, which is outside the park, and of several nearby communities as flames crept up slopes.

urn:contentItem:46YD-7370-01G6-B1KB-00000-00<published>1999-05-30T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:18:58Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>GENERAL AND NATIONAL NEWS</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>--Second NewsWatch--</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">(Space Shuttle)</p><p nitf:lede="true">No construction worker has ever worked this high before.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Two spacewalking astronauts from the shuttle "Discovery'' are working on the International Space Station, 385-kilometres above the earth.</p><p nitf:lede="true">-BODY- They've put into place two cranes that will be used to manoeuvre large items around during future spacewalks.</p><p>Tonight, the crew of Discovery will enter the station, which so far has only two rooms. (2) (Prairie Forest Fire)</p><p>A three-day-old forest fire is raging out of control near the northern Saskatchewan community of La Ronge.</p><p>However, there appears to be an upbeat sign from firefighters, who say at least the blaze is not spreading.</p><p>The fire, which covers eight square kilometres, has destroyed eight homes. (2) (With Prairie Fires)</p><p>Several hundred people who fled the northern Manitoba community of Cross Lake may be allowed to return today or tomorrow.</p><p>They were forced to flee by a forest fire that came within 300 metres of the town.</p><p>That blaze covers almost five square kilometres. (2) (Nova Scotia Budget)</p><p>Nova Scotia's minority Liberal government could walk a political tightrope on Tuesday when it tables its budget.</p><p>Finance Minister Don Downe is not promising it will be balanced.</p><p>The opposition Tories, who hold the balance of power in the legislature, have pledged to bring down Premier Russell MacLellan's government if there's a deficit. (2) (Double Homicide Suicide)</p><p>Police are investigating a double homicide-suicide at an aboriginal reserve 450-kilometres northwest of Edmonton.</p><p>It happened at Whitefish Lake First Nations, where a man fatally shot his common-law wife and a relative before turning the rifle on himself.</p><p>Police say the tragedy was likely fuelled by alcohol. (2) (Austrian Tunnel Fire)</p><p>At least one person is dead and 100 are injured after a fire in a tunnel in western Austria.</p><p>It started when a truck loaded with paint crashed into a car.</p><p>That set off a chain reaction of explosions and fires that burned for 15 hours.</p><p>About two dozen vehicles are nothing more than charred shells. (2) (Indy 500)</p><p>Funnyman Jay Leno is very serious about the job that lies ahead for him today.</p><p>The "Tonight Show'' host -- who is an avid car fan -- will drive the pace car for the Indianapolis 500.</p><p>Others who have done it include Chuck Yeager -- the first person to break the sound barrier -- and actor James Garner, who is a big car racing fan. (2) ---</p><p>(NewsWatch by Bill Marshall)</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:473C-50R0-01GV-K0VH-00000-00<published>1999-05-06T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:18:58Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>NEWS; Pg. C3</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>RESIDENTS FLEE AS FIRES THREATEN NORTHERN TOWNS</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>THE CANADIAN PRESS</nitf:byline><nitf:dateline>MARATHON, ONT.</nitf:dateline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Hundreds of people were evacuated from their homes yesterday while many more waited anxiously on standby as forest fires continued to close in on several communities across Northern Ontario.</p><p nitf:lede="true">The fire was so close to Pic Mobert First Nation that ashes were falling on Rose Parise's car as she sped out of the reserve and glanced nervously at clouds of black smoke.</p><p nitf:lede="true">"You could see the smoke on the north side of Highway 17," Parise said after arriving in nearby Marathon.</p><p>Parise, 41, was one of the first to get out of the White River-area community and flee the fire, estimated to be just six kilometres from the reserve.</p><p>About 450 Mobert residents, mostly travelling by bus, made the 60 kilometre journey to Marathon to bed down for the night at the town's community hall.</p><p>Mobert band manager Jerry Estey said thick smoke was visible from the band office.</p><p>"We were supposed to be (out of danger Wednesday), but then the wind shifted suddenly and everyone had to be out of here," Estey said.</p><p>The blaze also closed the Trans-Canada Highway to eastbound traffic at Highway 614, the turnoff for Manitouwadge.</p><p>More than 300 residents of Beardmore were evacuated to Geraldton earlier in the week as a 10,000-hectare fire bore down on their community near Lake Nipigon. They still have not been able to go home.</p><p>In White River, a raging forest fire shut down Domtar Forest Products and put 180 sawmill employees out of work temporarily because a 10,000-hectare blaze about four kilometres west of town damaged power transmission lines earlier in the week.</p><p>Sawmill manager Mel Jones said the workers won't be paid during the stoppage.</p><p>"The smell of smoke is in the town, and the winds are always changing," Jones said yesterday, as the community waited to see if they would have to flee.</p><p>Wawa is preparing to accept evacuees if smoke from the four-day-old forest fire grows any worse. The community is anticipating at least 150 seniors centre residents today.</p><p>"We do figure some people will be evacuated because of the smoke should the winds turn around tonight (yesterday)," police chief Bill Rose said.</p><p>South of Temagami, firefighters contained a 76-hectare forest fire.</p><p>"Its being held, but its not completely out," a ministry spokesman said.</p><p>The fire began Sunday afternoon a few kilometres south of Temagami, forcing more than 20 people to leave their homes. They returned Monday.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:5TPR-NR81-F103-300W-00000-00Authorities working to ID dead in California wild fires2018-11-11T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:18:58ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 0Authorities working to ID dead in California wild fires

PARADISE, Calif. - Authorities called in a mobile DNA lab and anthropologists to help identify the dead as the search goes on for victims of the most destructive wildfire in California history. The overall death toll from the outbreak of fires at both ends of the state stood at 25 Sunday and appeared likely to rise.

All told, more than 8,000 firefighters battled three large wildfires burning across nearly 1,000 square kilometres in northern and southern California, with out-of-state crews continuing to arrive and gusty, blowtorch winds making their return.

The worst of the blazes was in northern California, where flames reduced the town of Paradise, population 27,000, to a smoking ruin days ago and continued to rage in surrounding communities. The number of people killed in that fire alone, at least 23, made it the third-deadliest on record in the state.

Butte County Sheriff Kory Honea said the county was bringing in more rescue workers and consulted anthropologists from California State University at Chico because in some cases "the only remains we are able to find are bones or bone fragments."

"This weighs heavy on all of us," Honea said.

Authorities were also bringing in a DNA lab and encouraged people with missing relatives to submit samples to aid in identifying the dead after the blaze destroyed more than 6,700 buildings, nearly all of them homes.

The sheriff's department compiled a list of 110 people unaccounted for, but officials held out hope that many were safe but had no cellphones or some other way to contact loved ones.

Firefighters gained modest ground overnight against the blaze, which grew slightly to 440 square kilometres from the day before but was 25 per cent contained, up from 20 per cent, according to state fire agency, Cal Fire.

But Cal Fire spokesperson Bill Murphy warned that gusty winds predicted into Monday morning could spark "explosive fire behaviour."

Two people were also found dead in a wildfire in Southern California , where flames tore through Malibu mansions and working-class Los Angeles suburbs alike. The severely burned bodies were discovered in a long residential driveway in celebrity-studded Malibu, where those forced out of homes included Lady Gaga, Kim Kardashian West, Guillermo del Toro and Martin Sheen.

Flames also besieged Thousand Oaks, the Southern California city in mourning over the massacre of 12 people in a shooting rampage at a country music bar Wednesday night.

Fire officials said Sunday morning that the larger of the region's two fires, the one burning in and around Malibu, grew to 340 square kilometres and was 10 per cent contained. But the strong, dry Santa Ana winds that blow from the interior toward the coast returned after a one-day lull, fanning the flames.

The count of lost structures in both Southern California fires climbed to nearly 180, authorities said.

All told, an estimated 300,000 people statewide were under evacuation orders, most of them in Southern California.

Gov. Jerry Brown said he is requesting a major-disaster declaration from President Donald Trump that would make victims eligible for crisis counselling, housing and unemployment help, and legal aid.

Drought and warmer weather attributed to climate change, and the building of homes deeper into forests have led to longer and more destructive wildfire seasons in California. While California officially emerged from a five-year drought last year, much of the northern two-thirds of the state is abnormally dry.

In Paradise, a town founded in the 1800s, residents who stayed behind to try to save their properties or who managed to return despite an evacuation order found incinerated cars and homes.

Wearing masks because the air was still heavy with smoke, people sidestepped metal that had melted off of cars or Jet-Skis as they surveyed their ravaged neighbourhoods. Some cried when they saw nothing was left.

Jan McGregor, 81, got back to his small two-bedroom home in Paradise with the help of his firefighter grandson. He found his home levelled - a large metal safe and pipes from his septic system the only recognizable traces. The safe was punctured with bullet holes from guns inside that went off in the scorching heat.

He lived in Paradise for nearly 80 years, moving there in 1939, when the town had just 3,000 people and was nicknamed Poverty Ridge.

"We knew Paradise was a prime target for forest fire over the years," he said. "We've had 'em come right up to the city limits - oh, yeah - but nothing like this."

McGregor said he probably would not rebuild: "I have nothing here to go back to."

urn:contentItem:5SV7-0NN1-F105-64C3-00000-00Campbell River fire chief urges residents to respect fire ban2018-07-18T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:18:59ZLexisNexisNEWSCampbell River fire chief urges residents to respect fire ban

Campbell River's fire chief is urging locals to respect the fire ban that comes into effect today at noon – a prohibition covering all recreational fires, including beach fires, campfires and even backyard fires on private property.

"It is extremely important the public abide by the ban to prevent the risk of wildfire in our community," said fire chief Thomas Doherty in an email to the Mirror.

He stressed that fires can spread rapidly in current arid conditions.

"Sparks and embers can travel great distances, igniting spot fires in unexpected areas," he said, noting that 69 per cent of wildfires since the beginning of April were caused by people.

Beach-goers will have little excuse for ignoring the prohibition: signs will be posted near beaches advising the public about the ban, he said.

In a media release, Doherty said the fire department would continue monitoring conditions locally.

"If the weather changes and the risk drops enough, we will certainly let people know when and how they can have recreational fires in Campbell River," he said.

Complete fire ban (beach and backyard fires) goes into effect at 12pm today July 18th for the @CityCampbellRiv— Campbell River Fire (@RiverCityFire) July 18, 2018

The local prohibition comes as a response to a ban that comes into effect today for Vancouver Island, the Sunshine Coast, the Lower Mainland and the Gulf Islands.

Campfires and category-three fires – open fires larger than 2 metres high by 3 metres wide – will still be permitted in Haida Gwaii and in the "fog zone" – an area of the Island's western coast stretching roughly from Port Renfrew to Port Hardy. Fires are permitted along the strip within two kilometres of the highest tide line.

The prohibitions apply to all public and private land, unless specified otherwise in local government bylaws.

The ban covers everything from open fires to unauthorized stoves or campfire gear, tiki torches, fireworks, sky lanterns, burning barrels and "binary exploding targets," which are used for rifle target practice.

CSA and ULC-approved cooking stoves and campfire apparatus are still permitted, as long as flames don't go higher than 15 centimetres.

The fog zone, highlighted in purple, is exempt from the campfire ban as long as the area is within two kilometres of the highest tide line. (Coastal Fire Centre)

The ban comes into effect as the days get hotter, with no indication of rain in the immediate forecast.

Nathasha Broznitsky, fire information officer at the Coastal Fire Centre, said this year isn't as bad as 2017.

"The province in general was quite a lot drier this time last year," Broznitsky said.

"We had more rain in June than last year, and while the fire danger rating is largely high, in general we are doing less bad."

But since the beginning of April, almost 70 per cent of wildfires in the Coastal Fire Centre area – a vast region reaching as far as Tweedsmuir Park in northern B.C. – have been caused by humans.

Those fires deprive firefighters of badly needed resources, according to a media release from the BC Wildfire Service.

"Human-caused wildfires are entirely preventable, and can divert critical firefighting resource away from naturally occurring wildfires," the agency said in a statement announcing the ban .

Anyone found in contravention of the ban could be handed a $1,150 ticket, along with an "administrative penalty" of $10,000. If convicted in court, fire starters could face a $100,000 fine and a year in jail.

And a person found responsible for a wildfire may even be on the hook for "all firefighting and associated costs," according to the BC Wildfire Service.

For the most up-to-date information on fire bans, you can head to bcwildfire.ca. The agency also posts updates on its Twitter and Facebook feeds.

And if you need to report a forest fire or burning violation, you can call 1-800-663-5555 or text *5555.

-With files from Nicole Crescenzi, Victoria News.

urn:contentItem:4702-0MN0-01G6-81CY-00000-00<published>1999-06-23T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:18:58Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>WESTERN REGIONAL GENERAL NEWS</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>AM-Mushroom-Pickers, ; Eds: CORRECTS placeline to Kamloops, minor editing throughout; INDEX: Business, Environment, Food; Mushrooms growing in wake of forest fire prove lucrative crop</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>By Michele Young</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p>Kamloops Daily News</p><p nitf:lede="true">KAMLOOPS, B.C. (CP) - Last summer, forest fires at nearby Greenstone Mountain forced homeowners out of their residences and consumed hundreds of hectares of trees.</p><p nitf:lede="true">This summer, in the wake of the carnage, comes new life and a new business opportunity: mushrooms.</p><p nitf:lede="true">-BODY- Fire morels are a honeycomb-pocked fungus that rise from the soot and ashes the year after forest fires.</p><p>In the past two weeks, three mushroom buyers have set up their scales and camps along the Greenstone Mountain Road.</p><p>Professional and novice pickers armed with buckets or baskets hike through the eerie deadened forest, their hands and faces streaked with black.</p><p>It's a dirty job, but it can pay well.</p><p>Three Kamloops pickers coming down from the mountain were reluctant to disclose the value of their pails of mushrooms, but said they probably each netted about $120 for six hours work.</p><p>Stephen Dodds of Kamloops said it's good exercise and good money, once you know what to look for and where.</p><p>"They look like a burned fir cone,'' said Diane Phillips, who worked last summer as a firefighter on Greenstone Mountain and this year is trying her hand as a mushroom picker.</p><p>Morels, considered a delicacy by some, are fetching prices double from last year, said a buyer from Williams Lake, B.C., who was declined to give his name.</p><p>He said he was buying for Betty's Best, a company that dries the morels and ships them to Europe for sale.</p><p>He and the other buyers are all paying about $14 per kilogram.</p><p>Natural morel mushrooms commonly grow in poplar and willow stands but are prone to insect infestations. Fire morels aren't attacked by bugs.</p><p>Buyer Robin Caldwell of Salmon Arm, B.C., brought a dryer to dehydrate the mushrooms on site.</p><p>He buys for Mona Foods of Edmonton, which exports the dried fungus to North American and European markets.</p><p>"Some people think they're a delicacy,'' he said. "I don't like them.''</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:49HK-65K0-01G6-C043-00000-00<published>2003-09-12T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:18:58Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>WESTERN GENERAL NEWS</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Premier Gordon Campbell predicts a full agenda when he and his western counterparts meet with Governors of western U-S states.</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Premier Gordon Campbell predicts a full agenda when he and his western counterparts meet with Governors of western U-S states.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Campbell says cattle and beef exports, softwood lumber and strengthened wildfire protections will be his top priorities.</p><p nitf:lede="true">He says the ongoing closure of the border to cattle exports is devastating thousands of B-C residents.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>CP</p></bodyText></section><p>The Western Governors Association and western premiers meet this weekend in Montana. (BN)</p><p>(Air-India)</p><p>The Defence says, far from lying, Air India witness Inderjit Singh Reyat has given a better account of the bombings than ever before.</p><p>Lawyer Michael Code says it's difficult for the Crown to say a witness is lying -- especially when that witness is using the same story accepted for his guilty plea.</p><p>The Crown wants the court to declare Reyat a hostile witness, arguing the former accused has lied while testifying in the case against Ripudaman Singh Malik and Ajaib Singh Bagri.</p><p>They face charges of conspiracy and murder.</p><p>The judge will spend the weekend making a decision on the Crown application. (BN)</p><p>(B-C-Fires-Kelowna)</p><p>The Okanagan Mountain Park forest fire is no longer a danger to homes near Kelowna.</p><p>The Fire Commissioner's office has lifted an evacuation alert affecting 18-thousand people.</p><p>More than 200 homes were destroyed and 30 thousand people were evacuated when the Okanagan Mountain fire chewed through suburbs on the southern and eastern edges of Kelowna earlier this month. (CKOV)</p><p>(BC-Fires-Recovery)</p><p>Developers in Kelowna shouldn't worry about a building moratorium while the city reviews the effects of the Okanagan Mountain forest fire.</p><p>Kelowna's director of city planning, Ron Mattusi, says regulations are already in place -- now its up to staff to review what worked and what failed.</p><p>More than 200 homes in outlying, recently developed suburbs of Kelowna were devastated by the forest fire.</p><p>(CKOV)</p><p>(BC-Fires-Ban-Lifted)</p><p>Outdoor enthusiasts in southern B-C can return to the backcountry, as of midnight tonight.</p><p>The provincial government has lifted a ban on backcountry travel that has kept hikers, campers and hunters out of the woods since the Labour Day weekend.</p><p>Cooler, wet weather prompted the lifting of the ban.</p><p>However, forestry officials say conditions are still extremely dry and people are urged to venture into the backcountry only if absolutely necessary. (BN)</p><p>(Gas-Prices)</p><p>Gas prices have plummeted in Vancouver over the past two weeks but prices haven't budged in the rest of the province.</p><p>That's the finding of Calgary-based M-J Ervin and Associates.</p><p>The average price of gas in Vancouver is now pegged at 82.7 cents a litre -- more than nine cents lower than the record highs set August 26th.</p><p>Canada-wide, the average pump price this week was 77.1 cents per litre, almost seven cents lower that it was on august 26th. (CKNL)</p><p>(B-C Update by Beth Leighton)</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier The ban covers everything from open fires to unauthorized stoves or campfire gear, tiki torches, fireworks, sky lanterns, burning barrels and "binary exploding targets," which are used for rifle target practice.

CSA and ULC-approved cooking stoves and campfire apparatus are still permitted, as long as flames don't go higher than 15 centimetres.

The fog zone, highlighted in purple, is exempt from the campfire ban as long as the area is within two kilometres of the highest tide line. (Coastal Fire Centre)

The ban comes into effect as the days get hotter, with no indication of rain in the immediate forecast.

Nathasha Broznitsky, fire information officer at the Coastal Fire Centre, said this year isn't as bad as 2017.

"The province in general was quite a lot drier this time last year," Broznitsky said.

"We had more rain in June than last year, and while the fire danger rating is largely high, in general we are doing less bad."

But since the beginning of April, almost 70 per cent of wildfires in the Coastal Fire Centre area – a vast region reaching as far as Tweedsmuir Park in northern B.C. – have been caused by humans.

Those fires deprive firefighters of badly needed resources, according to a media release from the BC Wildfire Service.

"Human-caused wildfires are entirely preventable, and can divert critical firefighting resource away from naturally occurring wildfires," the agency said in a statement announcing the ban .

Anyone found in contravention of the ban could be handed a $1,150 ticket, along with an "administrative penalty" of $10,000. If convicted in court, fire starters could face a $100,000 fine and a year in jail.

And a person found responsible for a wildfire may even be on the hook for "all firefighting and associated costs," according to the BC Wildfire Service.

For the most up-to-date information on fire bans, you can head to bcwildfire.ca. The agency also posts updates on its Twitter and Facebook feeds.

And if you need to report a forest fire or burning violation, you can call 1-800-663-5555 or text *5555.

-With files from Nicole Crescenzi, Victoria News.

urn:contentItem:5NTV-TRH1-JCMN-Y16D-00000-00Portugal risks more and more deadly fires: experts2017-06-19T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:18:58ZLexisNexisPortugal risks more and more deadly fires: experts

Jun 19, 2017( Digital Journal: http://www.digitaljournal.com Delivered by Newstex) Highly exposed to global warming's climate-altering impacts, Portugal is likely to see more massive forest fires such as the one -- still raging -- that has killed at least 60 people this weekend, experts say.- Why Portugal, why now? Highly exposed to global warming's climate-altering impacts, Portugal is likely to see more massive forest fires such as the one -- still raging -- that has killed at least 60 people this weekend, experts say.- Why Portugal, why now?

-The Iberian peninsula encompassing Portugal and Spain is experiencing a warmer, drier June than usual, explains Thomas Curt, a researcher at France's Irstea climate and agriculture research institute.Added to that, the country has vast expanses of highly inflammable plants, including forests of pine and eucalyptus trees."Hotter air is synonymous with drier and more inflammable vegetation," said Curt. "The more the mercury climbs, so does the risk of fires and their intensity."Temperatures in the region have warmed by more than the global average over the past half century, according to a 2014 review of climate change impacts on Portugal.Heat waves have become more frequent, and annual rainfall slightly less, said the review published in the journal WIREs Climate Change.More frequent and pronounced heat waves are expected in future, accompanied by a "substantial increase" in fire risk -- "both in severity and in length of the fire season," it said.- Does global warming boost forest fire risk? - "It is certain -- we are experiencing a rise in temperatures," said Curt. The Northern hemisphere summer has lengthened over the past 50 years from July-to-August, to June-to-October now -- meaning a longer fire risk season.There has been an increase in major fires of more than 100 hectares, and so-called "megafires" of more than 1,000 hectares, the researcher added."It is truly a growing problem everywhere in the world, and notably in Mediterranean Europe." These mega blazes remain rare -- only about 2-3 percent of all fires -- but are responsible for about three-quarters of all surface burnt."Many analyses of climate change show that these major fires will become more and more likely," said Curt.- What to do? -In the short term, reinforce firefighting capacity, deploy patrols, set up watchtowers to raise the alarm, and ban fire-making everywhere.Over the longer term, human settlements and green areas will need to be substantially redesigned, experts say. Some forest will have to be cut back, undergrowth cleared, and residential areas moved further from scrubland and forest borders, to reduce the risk to life and property."The focus of efforts should shift from combating forest fires as they arise to preventing them from existing, through responsible long-term forest management," green group WWF said."Responsible forest management is more effective and financially more efficient than financing the giant firefighting mechanisms that are employed every year."In the yet longer term, added Curt, "of course, we need to curtail global warming itself."

urn:contentItem:46YD-70Y0-01G6-B316-00000-00<published>1999-05-03T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:18:58Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>GENERAL AND NATIONAL NEWS</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>--Third NewsWatch--</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">(School-Shooting-Alberta) (Audio: 09)</p><p nitf:lede="true">The prime minister's wife will be in Taber, Alberta today for the public memorial for the teenager killed in last week's high school shooting.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Aline Chretien will attend the service at W-R Myers High School, as will Reform Leader Preston Manning and Premier Ralph Klein.</p><p nitf:lede="true">-BODY- The service will be conducted by Reverend Dale Lang, the father of the 17-year-old boy who died.</p><p>Lang told his own congregation at his regular Sunday service that while he's angry Jason is gone, anger won't bring him back -- so he has forgiven his son's killer.</p><p>A 14-year-old boy is charged with murder and attempted murder in the wounding of another teen. (3) (Forest-Fire-Manitoba) (Audio: 11)</p><p>A wind-driven forest fire has forced 600 people to flee their homes on the eastern shore of Lake Winnipeg.</p><p>Residents of Seymourville, Hollow Water First Nation and Manigotagan (man-ih-guh-TAH'-gun) were told to evacuate Saturday night.</p><p>The flames are within four kilometres of the communities. (3) (Forest-Fire-Ontario)</p><p>In Northern Ontario, forest fires almost forced the evacuation of one-thousand people from Temagami (tuh-MAH'-guh-mee).</p><p>Firefighters late yesterday were able to tame the flames that raced across tree tops less than two kilometres from the town. (3) (Lakes-Levels)</p><p>Water levels are down in the Great Lakes -- in fact, they're at their lowest in a decade.</p><p>"Environment Canada says last year's dry and record warm weather has sent water levels in Lake Huron, Lake Erie and Lake Ontario plummeting, by between 50 and 65 centimetres since April of '98. Lake Superior's water level is down by 25 centimetres. (3) (Kosovo-NATO)</p><p>Power has been restored to most of Belgrade now, after a reported NATO attack on a major power plant.</p><p>The Yugoslav capital was in the dark for several hours last night -- the country's first major blackout since the allied bombing campaign began March 24th. (3) (Breasts-Melons)</p><p>Britain's biggest supermarket chain is asking growers to supply smaller melons.</p><p>The Daily Telegraph says Tesco's request followed a retail psychologist's's report that women shoppers subconsciously compare melons to the size of their breasts.</p><p>It concluded a current preference for smaller busts was the reason why big, fleshy melons were going unsold.</p><p>Tesco says since smaller melons were introduced two months ago, melon sales are way up. (3) ---</p><p>(NewsWatch by Karen Rebot)</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:4702-0K40-01G6-8421-00000-00<published>1999-05-05T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:18:58Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>QUEBEC-ONTARIO REGIONAL GENERAL NEWS</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>AM-Ont-North-Fire-Rdp ; INDEX: Environment, Social</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>By The Canadian Press</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p>Hundreds of people were evacuated from their homes Wednesday while many more waited anxiously on standby as forest fires continued to close in on several communities across Northern Ontario.</p><p nitf:lede="true">The fire was so close to Pic Mobert First Nation that ashes were falling on Rose Parise's car as she sped out of the reserve and glanced nervously at clouds of black smoke.</p><p nitf:lede="true">-BODY- "You could see the smoke on the north side of Highway 17,'' Parise said after arriving in nearby Marathon.</p><p>Parise, 41, was one of the first to get out of the White River-area community and flee the fire, estimated to be just six kilometres from the reserve.</p><p>About 450 Mobert residents, mostly travelling by bus, made the 60 kilometre journey to Marathon to bed down for the night at the town's community hall.</p><p>Mobert band manager Jerry Estey said thick smoke was visible from the band office.</p><p>"We were supposed to be (out of danger Wednesday), but then the wind shifted suddenly and everyone had to be out of here,'' Estey said.</p><p>The blaze also closed the Trans-Canada Highway to eastbound traffic at Highway 614, the turnoff for Manitouwadge.</p><p>More than 300 residents of Beardmore were evacuated to Geraldton earlier in the week as a 10,000-hectare fire bore down on their community near Lake Nipigon. They still have not been able to go home.</p><p>In White River, a raging forest fire shut down Domtar Forest Products and put 180 sawmill employees out of work temporarily because a 10,000-hectare blaze about four kilometres west of town damaged power transmission lines earlier in the week.</p><p>Sawmill manager Mel Jones said the workers won't be paid during the stoppage.</p><p>"The smell of smoke is in the town, and the winds are always changing,'' Jones said Wednesday, as the community waited to see if they would have to flee.</p><p>Wawa is preparing to accept evacuees if smoke from the four-day-old forest fire grows any worse. The community is anticipating at least 150 seniors centre residents today.</p><p>"We do figure some people will be evacuated because of the smoke should the winds turn around tonight (Wednesday),'' police chief Bill Rose said.</p><p>South of Temagami, firefighters managed to contain a 76-hectare forest fire.</p><p>"Its being held, but its not completely out,'' a ministry spokesman said.</p><p>The fire began Sunday afternoon a few kilometres south of Temagami, forcing more than 20 people to leave their homes. They returned Monday.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier DISCOVERY AIR INC ("DA.A,DA.DB.A-T;DCVRF-0") - Potential Transaction

Discovery Air Inc. ("Discovery Air" or the "Company") announced, at the request of Market Surveillance on behalf of the TSX, that the Company has been approached on a preliminary basis regarding a potential corporate transaction. The Company has not received a binding proposal and is in discussions as to the viability of such potential transaction.

There can be no assurances that a definitive transaction will result from any such proposal, and there may be limited available alternative transactions having regard to the Company's current ownership structure. The Company does not intend to comment further upon any potential corporate transaction, or alternative thereto, unless and until it deems further disclosure is appropriate, or required by law.

Forward-Looking Statements

Certain statements included above are forward-looking in nature. Such statements can be identified by the use of forward-looking terminology such as "expects," "may," "will," "should," "intend," "plan," or "anticipates" or the negative thereof or comparable terminology. Forward-looking statements include plans, expectations, or other statements that are not statements of fact, including with respect to any corporate or similar transaction and alternative thereto. Although Discovery Air believes that the expectations reflected in such forward-looking statements are reasonable, it can give no assurance that such expectations will prove to have been correct. Discovery Air's forward-looking statements are expressly qualified in their entirety by this cautionary statement. Discovery Air makes no commitment to revise or update any forward-looking statements in order to reflect events or circumstances after the date any such statement is made, except as required by applicable law.

About Discovery Air

Discovery Air is a global leader in specialty aviation services. We deliver exceptional air combat training, medevac equipped aircraft services, airborne fire services, air charter services, helicopter operations, and transport and logistics support to ensure operational readiness, health, safety and vital lifelines for our clients and the communities we serve.

Discovery Air Fire Services Inc. currently provides, and has provided for almost three decades, aerial fire surveillance, airspace and aircraft management, and air transport services in support of the Ontario government's forest fire management program. As well, DAFS' provides court-related air transport services to a variety of provincial government agencies which operate in northwestern Ontario (carried on by DAFS' charter division, Walsten Air).

Discovery Air's Class A common voting shares and unsecured convertible debentures trade on the Toronto Stock Exchange (symbols DA.A and DA.DB.A, respectively). Contact Information: Discovery Air Inc. Paul Bernards Chief Financial Officer 416-246-2684 ext. 3814 pbernards@discoveryair.com

urn:contentItem:4983-PS00-00RG-W06K-00000-00<published>2003-08-08T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:18:58Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>DOMESTIC NEWS</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Red Cross seeking $1 million in support of B.C. Fire Response</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:dateline>KAMLOOPS, BC, Aug. 8</nitf:dateline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">The Canadian Red Cross has established an <br/>initial fundraising target of $1 million to support recovery assistance for <br/>those affected by forest fires in British Columbia. <br/>    "We're aiming to provide for those basic needs of victims that are not <br/>already being addressed through the assistance of governments, insurance <br/>companies and other agencies," says Leslie Vryenhoek, spokesperson for the <br/>Canadian Red Cross.</p><p>"Our target is based on today's information, and may yet <br/>increase as we learn more." <br/>    Vryenhoek anticipates Red Cross assistance will help address needs <br/>relating to housing, food, clean-up, clothing, household furnishings and home <br/>repair. <br/>    "Support will be based on assessment of individual needs," says <br/>Vryenhoek. "We'll meet with those affected to determine the level and type of <br/>hardship they're facing. We're counting on the care and concern of Canadians <br/>to help alleviate this hardship." <br/>    To date, Red Cross has $209,000 in donations supporting its B.C. forest <br/>fire response. Corporate pledges have accounted for most of that total. "Our <br/>national disaster partners and many other corporations have been eager help - <br/>and we need that spirit to continue," says Vryenhoek. "There have also been <br/>some heart-warming stories related to individual donations, such as a $20,000 <br/>contribution from an anonymous B.C. resident." <br/>    Donations to the Red Cross B.C. Forest Fire Response Fund can be made by <br/>calling 1.800.418.1111, online at <url normalizedValue="http://www.redcross.ca">www.redcross.ca</url>, or by visiting any Red <br/>Cross office. In the unlikely event that donations exceed needs for this <br/>disaster, funds remaining would be directed to the Red Cross Canadian Disaster <br/>Relief Fund to help those affected by future disasters.</p><p>VIEW ADDITIONAL COMPANY-SPECIFIC INFORMATION: <br/><url normalizedValue="http://www.newswire.ca/cgi-bin/inquiry.cgi?OKEY=38887">http://www.newswire.ca/cgi-bin/inquiry.cgi?OKEY=38887</url></p></bodyText></nitf:body.content><nitf:body.end><contactInfo>CONTACT: urn:contentItem:49CY-73T0-00RG-W2SH-00000-00<published>2003-08-26T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:18:58Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>DOMESTIC NEWS</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Shell comes forward with more aid to B.C. fire victims</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:dateline>CALGARY, Aug. 26</nitf:dateline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Shell Canada today announced a donation of <br/>$15,000 in Formula Shell gift certificates to the Canadian Red CrossB.C. <br/>Forest Fire Relief campaign to help people throughout British Columbia who <br/>have been affected by the forest fire crisis. <br/>    Representatives from the Canadian Red Cross in B.C. will distribute the <br/>certificates to evacuees, who will then be able to purchase needed items such <br/>as fuel, water and batteries.</p><p>This $15,000 is in addition to $5,000 in <br/>certificates Shell donated to the Kamloops Emergency Social Services just over <br/>a week ago. <br/>    "In times of crisis neighbours pull together to help each other," said <br/>Linda Cook, President and CEO of Shell Canada. "On behalf of our employees and <br/>marketing partners, we want to assist fire relief efforts in B.C." <br/>    "This kind of support really makes a difference to families who have gone <br/>through some very difficult times this summer in B.C.," said Dan Allen, <br/>Western Canada Public Affairs Director for the Canadian Red Cross. "We are <br/>grateful for Shell's support and we'll be immediately directing their <br/>contribution to vulnerable people in the disaster areas." <br/>    The company's response to the fires in B.C. is not unique. Shell is also <br/>assisting fire relief efforts in the Crowsnest Pass area and, over the last <br/>five years, Shell and its employees have contributed time and money to various <br/>disaster relief efforts across the country.</p><p>VIEW ADDITIONAL COMPANY-SPECIFIC INFORMATION: <br/><url normalizedValue="http://www.newswire.ca/cgi-bin/inquiry.cgi?OKEY=88538">http://www.newswire.ca/cgi-bin/inquiry.cgi?OKEY=88538</url></p></bodyText></nitf:body.content><nitf:body.end><contactInfo>CONTACT: urn:contentItem:55PM-RBB1-JBJY-83GB-00000-00AuRico Gold Ore Processing at Kirkland Lake Suspended After Fire2012-05-22T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:18:59ZLexisNexisAuRico Gold Ore Processing at Kirkland Lake Suspended After FireBoston

AuRico Gold Inc. (AUQ.TO) reported that a forest fire located south of Kirkland Lake, approximately 70 kilometres east of the Young-Davidson mine site, has damaged several power poles and disrupted the main 115 kV power supply to the mine site. The mine is currently utilizing a separate 44 kV line (used for construction and development), which has not been affected. Ontario Hydro One is expected to re-establish full power to the mine within a week. Operations at the open pit have not been impacted and continue at normal levels, however ore processing has been suspended.

urn:contentItem:58BD-C751-JDV5-F05S-00000-00Fire rating high2013-05-02T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:18:58ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 1Fire rating high

MUSKOKA - The fire rating for the District of Muskoka is now set at high. Extreme caution must be taken with all open flames. Small fires are permitted in most rural areas of Muskoka keeping in mind that no daytime burning is allowed.

If you choose to have an evening fire, you must have adequate tools and water to extinguish the fire if the need arises and you must be with your fire at all times. Consult with your local fire department for outdoor burning regulations in your municipality: Bracebridge 705-645-5264; Huntsville 705-789-5201; Georgian Bay 705-538-2765; Lake of Bays 705-635-2272; Gravenhurst 705-687-3412; Muskoka Lakes 705-765-3156. The Muskoka fire season runs April 1 to Oct. 31 each year. The rating is verified daily and updated whenever the rating changes. The Muskoka fire danger rating is determined using the Fire Weather Index (FWI), an internationally used method for determining the risk of fires in open air. It uses factors such as the relative humidity, temperature, previous 24-hour rain amount, wind directions and wind speed in combination with the forest fuel type and loads to determine the risk of the forest to certain fire types. From this calculation the Forest Fire Danger Rating is made in consultation with the fire chiefs of the six area municipalities and the Ministry of Natural Resources.

urn:contentItem:5XKK-TGF1-F103-32VT-00000-00Power couple behind Perth's Knudsen Engineering have always hovered over water2019-11-21T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:18:58ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 1Power couple behind Perth's Knudsen Engineering have always hovered over water

For a relationship would spend so much time exploring the depths of waterways by developing marine sonar equipment, it is appropriate that Judith and Don Knudsen's relationship began on a bridge.

Judith had just arrived on the campus of the University of Waterloo, dropped her bags off in her room, and decided to explore the campus. She came to a bridge where Don was standing and they locked eyes - only for Don to tell her that freshmen were not allowed to cross the bridge, and that she would have to swim across.

Judith had wanted to go to a state college in upstate New York, but her father, a frugal engineer, saw that his daughter could save money by going to Waterloo. (He sweetened the deal to get her across the border, promising to increase her clothing budget if she went north.)

Either way, educationally, personally, and professionally, it was an investment that paid off - and Don later proposed to Judith on that very same bridge.

She later did finish her studies south of the border, at a business college in Buffalo, while Don stuck with Waterloo, getting degrees in mechanical engineering and fluid mechanics. He later went south himself, getting a PhD in ocean engineering in Boston. Don got his second master's degree at the Canadian Hydrographic Service in Burlington, Ont.

"If you've ever been out on the Big Rideau and used the maps with little numbers on them, they were produced (there)," Judith said.

The couple moved to Ottawa for Don to start work with the Canada Center for Remote Sensing.

NEW COMPANY

While it was a good job with the government, he quit working with the federal government to, in Judith's words, "build a better mousetrap," setting up Knudsen Engineering Inc. in 1981.

"You're going to start a company?" Judith remembers asking Don 38 years ago - in the midst of a recession. "Are you kidding me?"

The business was a family affair, with Don's brother Eric Knudsen joining them in the early days. (Eric died in 2002, and his portrait still hangs in the company boardroom.)

"Let's put our talents together," she said. "Don is a brilliant engineer," she adds, with obvious wifely pride. Her husband is a member of Mensa, and in 1989 won a Manning Award plus $25,000 for technological innovation. (The award is named after the former Alberta premier Ernest C. Manning - the father of federal Opposition Leader Preston Manning. The award singled Knudsen out for "his great talent in designing and developing a digital acoustic imaging system.")

INNOVATION

Over the years, the company has made various innovations in sonar technology, from multi-beam to single-beam sounding. They developed the DAISY system (Digital Acoustic Imaging System), as well as work on airborne remote sensory systems, which can, say, check out the area of damage done by a forest fire and "display it in real time as the airplane was flying over the area." They also took part in Arctic surveys, "where a lot of the land had not had any surveys."

"It's insane what we've done," she added.

But the innovations did not end there - when the company "exploded" into the world of dredging. For example, the technology is used in the port of Savannah, Georgia, which requires regular dredging.

"They need to keep it clear all the time," she said. Their technology can do a "presurvey to see how much," can be dredged. One frequency sent out to find out "where does the river bottom begin?" The second, lower frequency, can find out how much material can be dredged from the bottom.

They also innovated how information is recorded. The information used to be printed out on paper, but they adapted that to a digital system that recorded the information on a type of black box like airplanes use.

"Within a year, all of our competitors were coming out with black box recorders," she said.

Their equipment is now found on as many as 30 research vessels, from lakes as quiet as the Big Rideau, to the deep Marianas Trench, as seen by large poster-sized recordings of the depths of the ocean on the board room wall of the ocean - as well as of the Big Rideau.

"In some of this we've seen snowmobiles buried!" she said with a laugh, pointing to the Big Rideau diagram, showing the depth of the water, and the layers of sediment underneath.

The job has certainly kept her and her husband busy over the years.

"I always wanted to be a ballet dancer," said Knudsen. "Now, I just do tap dancing!"

THE KING OF ROCK AND ROLL AND A PRINCE TOO

The couple have been married for 52 years now. They had a full Roman Catholic wedding mass to start their married life off, but 50 years later, they went to Las Vegas with family and friends to do a different take on renewing their vows - by getting married, again, this time not by a priest, but by an Elvis Presley impersonator, at a chapel near Caesars Palace.

"Elvis married us," she said with a smile. Customers from as far away as Scotland came to the wedding, dressed in their traditional kilts, and other guests included a Marilyn Monroe impersonator.

The couple spend a portion of their year working from Florida, and she is a regular at trade shows around the world - including Monaco, where she can count on a familiar face to drop by her booth to say hello, Prince Albert II, the country's ruler.

"He's just a nice guy," she said. When she first met him, she admits that she went into full sell mode, asking if he had a vessel that needed sonar. He replied that he did not, at the time, but she pressed on.

"How about pops?" she asked, referring to Albert's father, Prince Rainier. "He has a vessel in the harbour."

If the prince was able to get back to her with an answer, "I can get you a great price."

Since then, she has made sure that the prince has received plenty of company swag, like baseball caps and even a barbecue apron, all bearing the name of Knudsen Engineering Ltd. of Perth.

"We are just so fortunate," she said.

urn:contentItem:5NSS-8VY1-JBVR-30PN-00000-00Ontario researchers to study dust for carcinogens after Fort McMurray fire2017-06-13T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:18:58ZLexisNexisNATIONAL,PRAIRIES/BC,ONTARIOOntario researchers to study dust for carcinogens after Fort McMurray fireOntario researchers to study dust after Fort Mac fireLiam CaseyThe Canadian Press

TORONTO - A group of Ontario researchers is travelling to Fort McMurray, Alta., next month to study dust left in homes from the forest fire that ravaged the city last year.

The team's work is among several studies that are being conducted on the health effects of the ferocious blaze that forced more than 80,000 people to flee.

Arthur Chan, an assistant professor of Chemical Engineering and Applied Chemistry at the University of Toronto, said his team has received overwhelming interest from "concerned" homeowners in Fort McMurray who are offering up their places to be tested.

"We hope we don't find anything," Chan said. "But we're looking for heavy metals and also some organic compounds that are potentially carcinogens. We're going to assess those levels and compare to what we know are normal levels in a home in Canada."

Chan and his team are looking to analyze residual ash from the blaze that consumed 2,400 homes after it hit the city last May.

On July 10, Chan and two of his students will head to Fort McMurray and begin collecting samples from homes in the city and nearby Fort McKay First Nation, which wasn't hit by the fire, but winds blew ash its way.

Chan said he was initially hoping to take samples from 40 places, but residents of 220 homes said they'll open doors to the researchers.

"We will try to go to as many places as we can," he said.

"We will pick up a few samples at each place. We'll try to look at areas that are more accessed, like the living room floor, and then other places that are less frequently cleaned, like the tops of doors."

Chan, who has a background in atmospheric chemistry, first got the idea for the study when he read a news article roughly a month after the wildfire began about people preparing to return to their homes. It got him thinking about the long-term effects of the blaze.

When the Canadian Institutes of Health Research, Alberta Innovates and the Canadian Red Cross put out a call for proposals to look at various health effects in the aftermath of the fire, Chan proposed his research, which won approval and funding from the group along with six other studies.

The other projects are looking at issues that range from the health effects of the blaze on first responders, to the mental health needs of children, to food safety.

Chan said his team will collect samples this summer, again in the fall and a final time next winter and will look to publish the results once their analysis is complete.

They'll also have residents fill out surveys to figure out if an insurance company came and cleaned homes, or if people did the task themselves, and will perform an analysis to see if certain measures led to higher or lower levels of contaminants.

urn:contentItem:545C-FK91-JCBF-523V-00000-00Slave Lake inferno blamed on arson Alberta rules out other causes through process of elimination2011-11-02T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:18:58ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. A7Slave Lake inferno blamed on arson Alberta rules out other causes through process of eliminationDean Bennett, John Cotter ;and Chris PurdyThe Canadian PressEDMONTON

The Alberta government says an unknown arsonist recklessly or deliberately ignited a raging forest fire that wiped out a third of the town of Slave Lake and left 2,000 people homeless.

Frank Oberle, minister of sustainable resources, said Tuesday the file has been turned over to the RCMP.

"It's extremely disappointing and my heart goes out to the people who lost homes or property," Oberle told a news conference.

"This further exacerbates that."

He said his investigators have determined it was arson because they've ruled out all other possible causes for the blaze, which destroyed 400 homes and businesses on May 15. He wouldn't say how they've definitively ruled out the fire was not set accidentally, such as by a careless camper failing to properly extinguish a fire.

"Our investigation eliminated all natural, industrial or accidental causes."

Oberle said investigators have determined where the fire started, but he wouldn't give the location because the scene is now part of a criminal investigation.

"We know there was no lightning at that site, no power line malfunction and no campfire located at that site, so a process of elimination gets us to the only reasonable conclusion."

The minister wouldn't say if there was evidence found at the scene to suggest arson, but added that a deliberately set forest fire is "relatively rare." A spokesperson for the department later clarified that there is some evidence, but refused to elaborate.

Supt. Marlin Degrand, in charge of criminal investigations for the RCMP in Alberta, said it will be "difficult" to pull together the investigative threads more than five months after the fact.

"After a review we will determine an appropriate course of action," said Degrand.

NDP Leader Brian Mason said while it was disturbing to hear arson may have been the cause, he wondered why it took the province five months to bring in the Mounties.

"As soon as they thought arson might be involved they should have brought in the RCMP," said Mason. "A parallel investigation would have been more prudent.

The town of Slave Lake, 250 kilometres northwest of Edmonton, is still struggling to get back on its feet after the devastating fire that was whipped by 100 km/h winds.

Total damage was pegged at $700 million, which insurance adjusters estimate makes it the second costliest disaster next to the Quebec-Ontario ice storm of 1998, which cost about $1.8 billion.

The fire forced all 7,000 residents to leave for two weeks as fire crews completed salvage work and police secured the area.

No one was hurt, but a firefighting helicopter pilot crashed on Lesser Slave Lake and died. There were 1,400 firefighters deployed along with 170 helicopters and tankers.

The province delivered almost $300 million in aid, including millions for modular homes for residents. Money was also delivered to nearby communities that set up evacuation centres.

In August, the province announced an independent review of how well it fought the fire and on the overall effectiveness of its fire management programs.

Whole neighbourhoods were flattened by a devastating wildfire that swept through Slave Lake, a town of 7,000, destroying more than 40 per cent of the buildings last May. Alberta has concluded the fire was caused by arson. Ian Jackson, The Canadian Press

urn:contentItem:5SRN-7RS1-F105-63VG-00000-00Wood smoke in Whitehorse neighbourhoods could pose health risk, officials say2018-07-06T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:18:59ZLexisNexisNEWSWood smoke in Whitehorse neighbourhoods could pose health risk, officials say

A first-of-its-kind study released earlier this week is warning about the winter air quality in four Whitehorse neighbourhoods.

The study measured the amount of fine particles in the air in nine locations over 16 months from 2015 to 2017.

It found that four neighbourhoods — Kopper King, Hidden Valley, Takhini Trailer Park and Riverdale — had high enough levels of fine particles in the air in the winter to warrant the government stepping in.

Janine Kostelnik, an environmental protection analyst with Environment Yukon, said that while those particles could come from dust or vehicle emissions, officials believe the Yukon's high levels are primarily due to wood smoke.

Yukoners might enjoy the smell of wood fire heaters in the winter, but Kostelnik said they need to know "that smelling that isn't nessicarily a good thing for your health because it does get into your lungs and has the potential to cause health problems."

According to national and Yukon standards the average amount of fine particulate matter in the air should not be more than 10 micrograms per cu. m. Data collected during the Yukon study shows that the Kopper King site slightly exceeded this threshold at approximately 10.25 micrograms per cu. m.

When neighbourhoods exceed 6.4 micrograms it is recommended that governments step in to stop further deterioration of air quality. Hidden Valley, Takhini Trailer Park and Riverdale all exceeded that level.

Kostelnik called the Yukon results an "indicator" that there might be a problem in those areas though she pointed out that national standards are normally based on three years worth of data.

"We always had thought that there was a problem but we couldn't really do anything without some sort of science around it," she said.

She said the neighbourhoods where higher levels were found are in valleys which makes it difficult for the particles to dissipate and are often subject to an inversion which can trap the particles over the neighbourhood.

Dr. Brendan Hanley, the Yukon's chief medical officer of health, said that while pollution in the air can irritate anyone, children and the elderly as well as those with respiratory or cardiac problems can be particularly at risk. Hanley said particles in the air from smoke can make people short of breath.

Data from other jurisdictions shows an association between higher level of air pollution and a risk of heart attack, he said.

"It's enough to say yeah, there's a risk and we need to do something about it."

The plan is to continue using the monitoring stations until at least 2020 though a few of the locations have been adjusted, Kostelnik said. That will give the territory enough data to officially compare its numbers to the national standards.

"Last winter was a relatively warm winter and that's why they want to average it out."

The government will also be installing a monitoring station in Dawson City and has a mobile station that the Department of Community Services will be using to monitor the air in the event of any major forest fire in the communities.

Hanley said there has been talk of possibly using the data to allow him to issue warnings if the air quality is poor.

"I think the message would be more about 'make sure that you're burning effectively,' he said.

"It could also say that, if you have a secondary source (of heat), maybe during these couple of days consider not using your wood heat but use your primary source or your alternate source of heat."

Between late July and early August officials will be hosting multiple open houses to raise awareness about proper burning techniques and the importance of a well-maintained stove. Dates for the open houses have not been set.

The government also plans to launch a public survey around that time to get a better sense of Yukoners' habits when it comes to burning wood, Koselnik said.

(CP) - Forest fire crews in the area battled 24 new blazes over the weekend, the B.C. Forest Service said.</p><p nitf:lede="true">"In the southeast fire centre, we had 24 incidents since Friday,'' said spokesman Steve Levitt.</p><p>To date, the southeast region has experienced 73 fires. Thirty-two have popped up since May 22.</p><p>-BODY- Of the fires found in the past week, lightning caused 15 blazes, while human activity is responsible for the rest.</p><p>The largest fire in the region is a 30-hectare blaze near Invermere.</p><p>"It's in a swampy, low lying area,'' Levitt said. "We couldn't use air tankers because the fire retardant would contaminate the water.''</p><p>To contain the blazes in the area, more than 200 forest service personnel have been sent into the region.</p><p>"We had limited rain this weekend,'' Levitt said. "So the rain we had isn't going to buy a big break.''</p><p>He said the entire area needs a longer, cooler wet spell before the forest fire hazards will drop and that isn't happening for the next five days.</p><p>A ban on opening burning is in place. While campfires are still allowed, Levitt urged campers to ensure their fires are properly extinguished. He suggested they have a bucket of water and a shovel on hand.</p><p>(Cranbrook Daily Townsman)</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata urn:contentItem:5HVW-TX71-JDV5-F172-00000-00Barn fire kills at least a dozen horses in Mount Forest2016-01-15T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:18:58ZLexisNexisNEWSBarn fire kills at least a dozen horses in Mount Forest

MOUNT FOREST- At least 12 horses have perished in a barn fire in the second such tragedy to hit southern Ontario this month.

The horses died late Thursday when fire erupted at a private farm in Mount Forest, Ont., northwest of Guelph. This fire follows a devastating blaze on Jan. 4, in which 43 standardbred horses perished in a stable fire at the Classy Lane Stables in Puslinch.

A person who answered the telephone at the Mount Forest property early Friday said all 12 horses were Arabian. He said he preferred not to comment further as they were "still trying to deal with it."

Mount Forest fire chief Dave Guilbault said he had been informed that one or possibly two horses had escaped the blaze, which erupted at about 10 p.m. and was extinguished by early Friday morning

"It's a large pasture here, so we know for sure one got out."

Guilbault said one person at the property, where the horses are both owned and boarded, suffered minor injuries.

"One gentleman was taken to hospital for precaution with a little bit of smoke inhalation and anxiety," he told The Canadian Press.

Guilbault said the blaze was contained to a single structure and that firefighters had "put up a water curtain ... so there's no damage to the house nearby."

He said although it was too early to say what caused the fire, he said there is speculation that a tractor might have caught on fire. Guilbault said firefighters were remaining on the scene until investigators from the Ontario Fire Marshal's office arrived in the morning to begin looking for the cause.

The Jan. 4 fire at the Classy Lane Stables in Puslinch has had a devastating impact on the horse racing community in southern Ontario.

[ Woodbine Racetrack pays tribute to 43 horses killed in barn fire ]

Co-owner Jamie Millier said the economic impact reached deep into the closeknit, horse-oriented community and that groomers, veterinarians, blacksmiths and other professionals in the industry would feel the effects of the deaths for months to come.

Trainer Dan Lagace, who lost seven horses he had worked with, said the fire was more than just a professional catastrophe - it was akin to losing members of a family.

The cause of the blaze remains under investigation.

nitf:lede="true">More than 50 cabins and two homes on Saskatchewan's Thunderchild reserve are a smouldering ruin.</p><p nitf:lede="true">One of hundreds of forest fires burning on the Prairies ravaged the northern resort community, about 200 kilometres northwest of Saskatoon.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>CP</p></bodyText></section><p>Dozens of residents from the northwest side of Turtle Lake were evacuated yesterday as the fire swept through the area.</p><p>Saskatchewan Environment says the fast-moving blaze was sparked by equipment working in the bush.</p><p>The fire is currently being held under control.</p><p>Thirty-five fires are burning across Saskatchewan -- seven are out of control.</p><p>But firefighters fear extreme drought conditions and lightning strikes could mean more fires in coming weeks.</p><p>(Alberta)</p><p>An Alberta wildfire information officer says the fire situation is extremely serious for Conklin.''</p><p>A massive forest fire in the northern part of the province is nearing the hamlet.</p><p>Fire officials have rated the blaze near Conklin at State Six -- the most dangerous level of forest fire.</p><p>Firefighting crews have been put on alert to pull out if the situation worsens.</p><p>Gusting winds fanned the flames, pushing two fingers of the fire within about nine kilometres both north and south of the community today.</p><p>More than 250 residents remain evacuated.</p><p>The fire has burned more than 14-hundred square kilometres.</p><p>(Manitoba)</p><p>In Manitoba, crews contained a 38-square-kilometre fire.</p><p>The blaze had threatened two communities near the Saskatchewan boundary.</p><p>A spokesman for Manitoba Conservation says an evacuation alert was lifted today for residents of Powell and Barrows.</p><p>But the spokesman says the fire is still classified as out of control because of its size.</p><p>(CP)</p><p>JMG</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata
